title: Margaret de Audley, 2nd Baroness Audley
text:
Margaret de Audley, "<a href="suo%20jure">suo jure</a>" 2nd Baroness Audley and Countess of Stafford (c. 1318 – 7 September 1349) was an English noblewoman. She was the only daughter of <a href="Hugh%20de%20Audley%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Gloucester">Hugh de Audley, 1st Earl of Gloucester</a>, by his wife <a href="Margaret%20de%20Clare">Lady Margaret de Clare</a>. Her mother was the daughter of <a href="Joan%20of%20Acre">Joan of Acre</a>, Princess of England; thus making Margaret a great-granddaughter of King <a href="Edward%20I%20of%20England">Edward I</a> by his first consort, <a href="Eleanor%20of%20Castile">Eleanor of Castile</a>. As the only daughter and heiress of her father, she succeeded to the title of 2nd Baroness Audley [E., 1317] on 10 November 1347.
Marriage and issue.
Margaret was abducted by <a href="Ralph%20de%20Stafford%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Stafford">Ralph, Lord Stafford</a>, who had helped <a href="Edward%20III%20of%20England">Edward III</a> take the throne. At the time, her worth was at least £2314 a year, which was more than ten times Stafford's own estates. (However, he eventually rose to <a href="Earl%20of%20Stafford">Earl of Stafford</a> in 1350.) After the abduction, her parents filed a complaint with the king, but Edward supported Stafford. In compensation, the king appeased Hugh and Margaret by creating Hugh the 1st <a href="Earl%20of%20Gloucester">Earl of Gloucester</a>.
Margaret de Audley and Stafford married before 6 July 1336. They subsequently had two sons and four daughters:
